Authors:
Mika Bendiksby, Reidar Haugan, Toby Spribille, Einar
Timdal
Title:
Molecular phylogenetics and taxonomy of the Calvitimela
aglaea complex (Tephromelataceae, Lecanorales)
Keywords:
phylogenetic taxon concept; lichens, mcm7, morphology,
mtSSU, nrITS, tef1, thin layer chromatography
Abstract:
Contributing to the process of reassigning lecideoid
lichens to natural generataxa, we assess phylogenetic relationships and
species delimitation in the Calvitimela aglaea complex
(Tephromelataceae) using DNA sequence data as well as
morphological/anatomical and chemical characters. Phylogenetic analysis
of nuclear (ribosomal ITS, mcm7, and tef1) and mitochondrial (ribosomal
SSU) DNA sequences reveals Mycoblastus as sister to a strongly supported
clade comprising Calvitimela, Tephrolema and Violella. Members of these
three genera fall into six strongly supported subclades with no support
for resolution among them. Two of these are represented by Tephromela
and Violella, which are readily circumscribed also morphologically. The
remaining four subclades encompass members of Calvitimela, which,
whether lumped or treated separately, remain difficult to distinguish
morphologically. Our results reveal previously unrecognized evolutionary
lineages at both the genus and species level. Morphological and/or
chemical synapomorphies could be detected for only some of these,
resulting in phenotypically cryptic lineages at both the genus and
species level. Rather than retaining unsupported assemblages, or lumping
and thereby losing information about evolutionary history, we have opted
for a splitting strategy in our taxonomic treatment for the Calvitimela
aglaea complex. Thus, we describe three new subgenera (Calomela,
Paramela, and Severidea) and two new species (CalvitimelaS. cuprea and
CS. livida), all mainly delimited by DNA sequence data.
